channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ROO-3184] RooBot addon registration does not work
item.description:
All (http://spring-roo-addons.googlecode.com/svn/repo/repository.xml) Addons have disappeared (being removed?) from the RooBot registry:http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/roobot/roobot.xml

The (re)registration attempts following the instructions (http://static.springsource.org/spring-roo/reference/html/simple-addons.html#d4e3384) lead to nothing. I have not "received a response from RooBot indicating that the processing of your repository has started" nor I can find related trace in the roobot-log: http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/roobot/roobot-log.txt
item.summary: RooBot addon registration does not work

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Some of my addons also disappeared, while an older one (roo-equals-addon) still exists.
Mail to s2-roobot@vmware.com (to register the addons again) seems to have no effect.
We'll try to get to this asap. Andrew and I have been on some other urgent VMware/SpringSource work recently and haven't had time to investigate.
Any progress on this? I don't mean to nag, is there some workaround I can use to search for and install Roo add-ons?

1. Manually download the mysql java connector from here - http://www.mysql.com/downloads/connector/j/
You will get an archive from this download, extract the jar file inside the archive in any directory.
2. In your Roo shell issue the following command -
osgi start --url file:///tmp/mysql-connector-java-5.1.20-bin.jar
(Assuming you have downloaded the latest version into /tmp directory)

That might work for mysql, but all the other plugins are missing too, there's only 17 being listed at the moment. Is there a central repository url where we can manually grab and install the plugin bundles?

any jar file can be add use osgi start --url file
ex) if u got error at

roo> database reverse engineer --package ~.domain --schema PUBLIC
addon search --requiresDescription "#jdbcdriver,driverclass:org.h2.Driver" found no matches
JDBC driver not available for 'org.h2.Driver'

download jar file or add pox.xml
and copy url of the file
and run this command at roo shell

roo> osgi start --url file:C:\Users\yh\.m2\repository\com\h2database\h2\1.3.164\h2-1.3.164.jar

and try again
roo> database reverse engineer --package ~.domain --schema PUBLIC

u can see that command work

Currently roo addon list yields only two addons:

roo> addon list 
2 found, sorted by rank; T = trusted developer; R = Roo 1.2 compatible
 
ID T R DESCRIPTION -------------------------------------------------------------
 
01 - Y 0.9.9 Installs jQuery UI
 
02 - Y 0.9.0 Adds the coffeescript maven compiler
 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
[HINT] use 'addon info id --searchResultId ..' to see details about a search result
 
[HINT] use 'addon install id --searchResultId ..' to install a specific search result, or
 
[HINT] use 'addon install bundle --bundleSymbolicName TAB' to install a specific add-on version

Which is consistent with roobot.xml as of writing this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
 
<roobot published="2012-08-21 04:58:32">
 
  <bundles>
 
    <bundle bsn="org.sillyweasel.addons.jqueryui" uaa-ranking="0.0">
 
      <comments/>
 
      <versions>
 
        <version description="Installs jQuery UI" last-updated="20120413040238.786" major="0" micro="9" minor="9" name="jqueryui" obr-url="http://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/repository.xml" pgp-key-id="0xB6F65A34" roo-version="*" size="146392" url="httppgp://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/org/sillyweasel/addons/jqueryui/org.sillyweasel.addons.jqueryui/0.9.9/org.sillyweasel.addons.jqueryui-0.9.9.jar">
 
          <shell-commands>
 
            <shell-command command="jquery api install" help="provide jquery API"/>
 
            <shell-command command="jquery ui install" help="provide jqueryui"/>
 
          </shell-commands>
 
        </version>
 
      </versions>
 
    </bundle>
 
    <bundle bsn="org.sillyweasel.addons.coffeescript" uaa-ranking="0.0">
 
      <comments/>
 
      <versions>
 
        <version description="Adds the coffeescript maven compiler" last-updated="20120413040238.786" major="0" micro="0" minor="9" name="coffeescript-addon" obr-url="http://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/repository.xml" pgp-key-id="0xB6F65A34" roo-version="*" size="10200" url="httppgp://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/org/sillyweasel/addons/coffeescript/org.sillyweasel.addons.coffeescript/0.9.0/org.sillyweasel.addons.coffeescript-0.9.0.jar">
 
          <shell-commands>
 
            <shell-command command="coffeescript setup" help="Install the CoffeeScript compiler"/>
 
            <shell-command command="coffeescript remove" help="Remove the coffeescript compiler"/>
 
          </shell-commands>
 
        </version>
 
      </versions>
 
    </bundle>
 
  </bundles>
 
  <pgp-keys>
 
    <pgp-key id="0xB6F65A34">
 
      <pgp-key-description text="Ken Rimple (Silly Weasel) (ken.rimple@gmail.com)"/>
 
    </pgp-key>
 
  </pgp-keys>
 
</roobot>

@leeyounghun's workaround is only usable if you know the download location of the bundle jar beforehand, which is proving difficult.

seems as these errors occur because the domain sillyweasel.org is parked.
http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/roobot/roobot-log.txt

01:03:32.928 - Unable to load OBR at: http://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/repository.xml
java.io.IOException: Server returned HTTP response code: 403 for URL: http://nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081/nexus/content/repositories/releases/repository.xml

is there a cron job, which updates the local sources from nexus.sillyweasel.org:8081?

For people trying to get started with Roo, this isuue is a major roadblock.

A selling point of Roo is the ease of integration (Eclipse via STS), RAD startup-time, etc... but with this issue, there's no easy way (short of workarounds) to get the STS integration working and the tutorials evaluated.

I have multiple developers that are looking to "move on" because of this (now long-standing) issue. I'd like to give Roo fair assessment against competitors but am presently unable.

Thanks.

I have moved to cakePHP. "Bake" offers the same things. http://book.cakephp.org/1.3/view/1522/Code-Generation-with-Bake
BTW: PHP is faster than any java app.

I agree with Mike; this is a major road block;
Why can't I just configure a different repo?
In the $ROO_HOME/conf/confg.properties I only see

roobot.url=http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/roobot/roobot.xml.zip

another URL which fails, this time with 404
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<Error><Code>NoSuchKey</Code><Message>The specified key does not exist.</Message><Key>roobot/roobot.xml.zip</Key><RequestId>EC111FDC2E352005</RequestId><HostId>mlP9AmzkLs6ZzE2icYDOaQVtx0xX+G8L+ik+1sSPmTbUDbMsUy8mNpyYwHQdH9Vj</HostId></Error>

We are still trying to get to the bottom of the problem. The hardware and tcServer which runs roobot has been shutdown yet there is still some process trying to read the now non-existent sillweasel domain which is preventing updates to the database to allow add-ons to appear for downloading in shell. Allbeiit we're not full time on the issue due to work for SpringOne , but we hope to have the problemm resolved soon.

Thanks a lot, Alan,
hope your are lucky, soon.

BTW: For a production usage, this would be a disaster, wouldn't it?

Meanwhile I tried the "osgi start" command, but with no luck;
but I'll go to the forum with this.

Can we assume this will work with the upcoming 1.2.3 release? This thread seems to only be related to publishing addons, but currently I am unable to retrieve or install any addons via STS 3.0 or within the Roo 1.2.2 command shell.

fwiw: just started the roo console, which welcomes me with what seems to be a twitter post:
Welcome to Spring Roo. For assistance press TAB or type "hint" then hit ENTER.
@krimple: On my way to the @RichmondJUG to speak about @SpringRoo add-ons. Looking forward to it!

... so am I (sorry for being a bit sarcastic )

If you need one of the DBdriver mapper h2/mysql there is an easy workaround. Type this in to your roo shell

osgi obr url add --url http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/repository.xml
 
osgi obr deploy --bundleSymbolicName org.springframework.roo.wrapping.mysql-connector-java
 
osgi obr deploy --bundleSymbolicName org.springframework.roo.wrapping.h2

for further background check out my blog entry: http://lalyos.github.com/blog/2012/09/24/spring-roobot-workaround/
This has been resolved. We apologise for the delay and inconveniences caused.

Doesn't seem to be resolved. I experienced the same problem again with a freshly installed Roo 1.2.2.RELEASE [rev 7d75659] today. There are only 9 addons found:

roo> addon list
 
9 found, sorted by rank; T = trusted developer; R = Roo 1.2 compatible
 
ID T R DESCRIPTION -------------------------------------------------------------
 
01 - Y 0.1.1 A Roo add-on that configures a Maven site.
 
02 - Y 1.0.0.0001 This bundle wraps the standard Maven artifact:
 
       google-collections-1.0.0.
 
03 - Y 1.1.0.RELEASE Installs jQuery Project
 
04 - Y 2.0.0.v201106070531 This bundle wraps the standard Maven artifact:
 
       org.eclipse.xtext.xtend2.lib-2.0.0.v201106070531.
 
05 - Y 2.3.1 This bundle wraps the standard Maven artifact:
 
       org.eclipse.xtext.xtend2.lib-2.3.1.
 
06 - Y 2.0.0.v201106070531 This bundle wraps the standard Maven artifact:
 
       org.eclipse.xtext.xbase.lib-2.0.0.v201106070531.
 
07 - Y 10.0.1.0001 This bundle wraps the standard Maven artifact:
 
       google-guava-10.0.1.
 
08 - Y 0.9.3 Installs the Spock testing engine. You can create tests using
 
       Spock's Specifications, and use the Spock Spring API
 
09 - Y 1.0.0.RELEASE Adds the coffeescript maven compiler
 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

UPDATE: ROO-3294 seems to be a duplicate of this. Jon describes the same behaviour with exact the same results from "addon list". Therefore, I doubt that this was just a glitch.

I am new to Roo. I have never seen addon work properly. And, I noticed that in the hint for addon list there is something about a max number per page. How does one page through results if the max is nine per page?

Howdy-

I just tried:
roo> pgp trust --keyId 0xBF0451C0
roo> download accept terms of use
roo> addon install bundle --bundleSymbolicName com.vaadin.spring.roo.addon

Got as far as accepting the terms of use, and then got:
Could not find specified bundle with symbolic name: com.vaadin.spring.roo.addon

addon does not seem to be working.
-srd3
I'm currently seeing this again. There are only 9 entries in the addon list. Any ideas?

The Issue still stands.
No new Add-On can be install for new project.

I am trying to go through a tutorial using eclipse and I am running into this issue. Can someone change the status of this issue to unresolved?

I have the same problem too, please reopen this issue. I find only 1 addon, and in the http://spring-roo-repository.springsource.org/roobot/roobot.xml file there's only 1 addon listed.

roo> addon list

testing.

This is a real showstopper for me. We have been using roo as our rad tool for prod development for the last 2 years and now all of a sudden, I'm dead in the water. Is there an ETA on this?
Thanks Lajos papp for your workaround!! I spent hours trying to solve this problem and finally your solution worked for me.
